instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.WS_KBD_ONOFF_L: What is WS_KBD_ONOFF_L? WS_KBD_ONOFF_L is a signal that comes from the keyboard that tells the SMC that the power button has been pressed.  L means whatever before the L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v. This signal directly affects SMC_ONOFF_L.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-09 no keyboard (power, alt, cmd, works)
threads.message:
Hi there,

I have an issue with a 2015 MBP - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (slight water damaged) which after ultrasonic clean i replaced the DC board fuse and now works well except for the keyboard which has got me stumped. everything works including the trackpad and i have fitted a new trackpad & trackpad flex cable but all keys on the keyboard is not working with the exception of the (power button, ctrl, cmd, alt) which works just fine. Have tested new keyboard as well.

Test points on keyboard connector:


Pin 4 (<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H_TPAD</SIGNAL>) = 3.42v
Pin 5 (<SIGNAL>WS_KBD_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>) = 3.3v
Pin 30 (<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_TPAD</SIGNAL>) = 3.3v

Any ideas on what to test / check next?

Kind Regards

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-09 no keyboard (power, alt, cmd, works)
threads.message: Check power to <CHIP>U4820</CHIP>/30. Also check the data lines to the trackpad <SIGNAL>I2C_IOXP_SCL</SIGNAL> and SDA. Make 100% sure you trackpad and cable are good as that is the most common cause.
